pullRequest.title: Resolves #1012: BITMAP_VALUE index cursors can be bit-wise merged
pullRequest.bodyText:
Overall approach:

Given a set of BITMAP_VALUE indexes differing in the finest grouping key.
Given a query with:

Equality conditions on the coarser grouping keys.
A Boolean expression over conditions on the finest keys.
Optional inequalities on the position value.


Produce a plan that:

Does covering index entry scans for each of the sub-conditions.
Combines the streams of bitmaps from those scans using the bit-wise analogues of the Boolean operators among them.
Filters out any bitmaps that end up empty (such as for AND with no shared positions within the position range of that bitmap) to cut down result size.



Questions for @normen662:

Is it correct for ComposedBitmapIndexQueryPlan to not have child plans or should RecordQueryCoveringIndexPlan really be RecordQueryPlanWithChild too? How do these fit into the Quantifier scheme?

commit.message:
Adjust visibility of MergeCursor classes and methods
Fix various warnings that are now checked for a public class.
Make the result of planCoveringAggregateIndex more generally useful.

nodes.bodyText: This should be considered a binary-incompatible change of the stable API.
This should be considered a binary-incompatible change of the stable API.
nitpick -- maybe this should be named something tryBuild
this should call structuralEquals() as it is a plan
this should call structuralHash() as it is a plan
all these getters are now done per record and could be done once per execute(). Not sure if in one of these you have anything computationally expensive going on...

nodes.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
             * A {@link RecordCursor} doing as bit-wise merge of bitmaps from two or more {@code BITMAP_VALUE} indexes.
          
          
            
             * A {@link RecordCursor} doing a bit-wise merge of bitmaps from two or more {@code BITMAP_VALUE} indexes.
I suppose the construction of indexNodes should be delayed until after bitmapIndexes.isEmpty() is checked... Not that I expect that change will make any, like, measurable difference in performance

commit.message: Defer a map creation since it's easy

nodes.bodyText: This is a little unclear to me. It's separating the satisfied filters and the unsatisfied filters, but the satisfied filters might not be on the group (unless I'm missing something). In particular, if there's a filter on the position key, does that belong as a member of groupFilters?
Is there actually a bloom filter in this continuation, or was this added accidentally?

Hm, something seems fishy about how all of the operate methods for the binary operators are the same except for this line (I think?). Like, that there should be a BinaryOperator (or NAryOperator or something) method with an abstract operateOnByte method that the implementations should use or something.
Hm, I guess the bitmap index function doesn't support sorting descending by position? That's probably fine (at least for now)

It's a little weird that planning takes an FDBRecordStore here. I think the only things it uses are the meta-data and which indexes are readable. Should this take those two items instead (or a RecordQueryPlanner if the appropriate accessor methods on the meta-data and record store state are added)?
There's something about the API that is a little weird in general (like having separate tryBuild and tryPlan methods). Like, it would seem like most users would want a method that's closer to the plan method in the test class, or a variant that takes a RecordQuery that provides the record types, the required results, and the filter (and errors on a sort?).

This parameter in general, taking a query, was confusing to me for a long time, I guess because it wasn't clear to me that this was intended to be a "query prototype" to be filled in with the appropriate filter when planning the various legs.

Hm, so the idea is that the base query provides the type(s) and the required results and the index node provides the filter, and then, as a side effect, the final planned index node's filter will end up in the query builder, but that's not a desired side effect (per se), it just "happens".
I wonder if instead the object (or method) should take a query (which I also suggested above), and then it can call .toBuilder on the query here to get a temporary object and override the filter.
What is the purpose of additionalKey here?

Hm, this doesn't seem right to me. In particular, I think if you had disjoint ranges of positions for the physical bitmaps from different indexes, then I think it won't merge them together correctly, if I understand how those work. (This doesn't matter for ANDs, but for ORs and NOTs, etc.)

Should it be part of the planning that the parameter for the size needs to be the same? It seems like the "ideal" version would figure it out then, but maybe it's sufficient for the time being for it to be an error here.

Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                        throw new RecordCoreArgumentException("not enough child cursors provided to UnionCursor")
          
          
            
                        throw new RecordCoreArgumentException("not enough child cursors provided to ComposedBitmapIndexCursor")

I think this could use a few more tests. Namely:

Something that uses not. If there's a way to get an XOR, then that would be nice too, but I don't think we have that in our API (nor do we simplify "(a ∨ b) ∧ ¬ (a ∧ b)" into "a ⊕ b", I don't think).
Something that has a union of elements with disjoint physical bitmaps in the index. Something like (using a pseudo-SQL syntax) SELECT bitmap(rec_no) FROM MySimpleRecord WHERE num_value_2 = 3 OR num_value_2 = 4 where all of the records with num_value_2 = 3 are in one position group and all of the records where num_value_2 = 3 are in a different one.

Oh, I was definitely confused by nextPosition > position. (For whatever reason, I find it easier to reason about if the comparison is the other way around.) Okay, now I understand what this is doing, and I think it looks correct to me. Maybe it could use a comment explaining that it's choosing all of the bitmaps with the minimum position?
Should this also reject the query if query.getSort() != null?

Yeah. I...think it would reverse the whole bitmap, though I suppose in some sense, that's a little Endian vs big Endian debate. In any case, leaving it as not allowed (at least for now) rather than trying to settle that debate seems like the right call to me.
